results.title: Somalia Moves to Defuse Tensions Both at Home and Abroad
results.abstract: The Somali leader dropped his divisive bid to extend his term, and the country also moved to mend fences with its neighbor Kenya, restoring diplomatic relations.

results.title: Three Months After Coup, Myanmar Returns to the ‘Bad Old Days’
results.abstract: Police are now stopping random people on the streets. A group of secret informers has reappeared. The killings continue, but so does the resistance.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: Protesters running as security forces arrive during a crackdown, in Ahlone township, in April.

results.title: Germany will allow anyone 18 and older to get the AstraZeneca vaccine.
results.abstract: The government is also recommending that doctors be allowed to give a second dose before the recommended 12 weeks in order to speed up vaccinations.

multimedia.caption: A man is vaccinated with AstraZeneca in Pforzheim, southern Germany, on Wednesday.

results.title: Russia says one dose of its Sputnik V vaccine protects well enough to skip the second dose.
results.abstract: The announcement clears the way for getting more people vaccinated faster, though with less complete or long-lasting immunity.

multimedia.caption: A Russian medical worker preparing a shot of Russia’s Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine in Simferopol, Crimea, in April.

results.title: From Fish to Warships: How a Small Britain-France Dispute Escalated
results.abstract: A dispute over fishing rights ballooned, leading the countries to send ships to the island of Jersey in the English Channel. No, they’re not likely to go to war.

multimedia.caption: French fishermen, angry over the loss of access to waters off their coast, have gathered their boats in protest off the English Channel island of Jersey.
French fishermen, angry over the loss of access to waters off their coast, have gathered their boats in protest off the English Channel island of Jersey.

results.title: Hong Kong Pushes ‘Fake News’ Label as Media Face ‘Worst of Times’
results.abstract: The police distributed a magazine denouncing “rumors and lies,” and have warned news outlets against undermining national security.

results.title: ‘Are You Like This Doggy?’ U.S. Embassy Asked Chinese Students. It Backfired.
results.abstract: In a social media post about visa applications, the consular section in Beijing posed a question that some critics called racist.

multimedia.caption: The U.S. Embassy in Beijing. The post could be read as a ham-handed attempt to be cute. But at a moment of heightened nationalism on the Chinese internet, it set off a wave of criticism.

results.title: A town in Japan spent Covid relief funds on a giant squid statue.
results.abstract: A $230,000 statue is part of an effort to revive tourism in the fishing town of Noto. Critics call it a waste of money as Japan struggles to contain a new outbreak.

results.title: E.U. Leader Says Bloc Is Willing to Discuss Patent Waiver for Covid Vaccines
results.abstract: The head of the European Commission said the E.U. would consider proposals on waiving intellectual property rights, following the Biden administration’s reversal of U.S. policy.
